ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Open Question Re: Significance of Composition of Generation Zero
ygData.msgSnippet: Cherry-picking the most-fit solutions from a random set of initial solutions seems equivalent to bootstrapping NEAT with random search. Random search is

Subject: Re: [neat] Open Question Re: Significance of Composition of Generation Zero
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=282483363; y=_QbQSZzbbsu0gCFfbCweiV6PbiBQwOa_Lk-PuvBd2wanARo
X-Yahoo-Profile: slakmehl

Cherry-picking the most-fit solutions from a random set of initial
solutions seems equivalent to bootstrapping NEAT with random search.
Random search is inferior to genetic search for most domains to which
you would apply NEAT, so intuitively I would think that you wouldn't
see a tangible benefit from this approach.  In fact, you could be
introducing damaging sampling bias by pointing NEAT away from optima
that might be too small to hit with the initial population, but may be
reachable from initial low-fit individuals.

My guess is that you won't do any harm, but nor will you see
improvement.  It's easy enough to test, though, so give it a shot.  My
intuitions are wrong often enough.

On Jan 3, 2008 6:45 PM, afcarl2 <a.carl@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
> Is there any significance to the composition of generation zero beyond
> that of providing a radomized evaluation/starting point of the design
> space? If the composition is a set of random points in the design
> space, is one population/set of random starting points any different
> than any other, except for perhaps getting lucky in regards to a higher
> fitness potential via complexification?
>
> The function of the NEAT params are focused on transition to subsequent
> generations, and as such appear neutral wrt generation zero, except for
> perhaps population size.
>
> If this is the case, is there any loss of generality by generating
> multiple populations of generation zero, and cherry-picking the best as
> the population to proceed with NEAT evolution?
>
>
